bestBHT.bht: Jesus teaches about humility and warns against seeking the highest place at a feast. True exaltation comes from the Host, not through self-promotion. The mention of a wedding feast points to the deeper meaning of the Kingdom of God. Jesus avoids personal references, alluding to a different kind of entertainment. Instead of taking the chief place at the table, he advises against sitting in the highest room, as a more honorable person might be bidden and better suited for that position.

Henry Alford: All that false humility, by which men put themselves lowest and dispraise themselves of set purpose to be placed higher, is, by the very nature of our Lord’s parable, excluded.
The exaltation at the hands of the Host is not to be a purposed end to the guests, but will follow true humility.

The whole of this has, besides its plain reference, a deeper one, linked into it by the important word wedding, carrying with it all that meaning which it always has when relating to the Kingdom of God.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Our Lord avoids the appearance of personality...
...this delicate allusion to a different kind of entertainment...
Philip Schaff: The figure suggests a reference to the feast of the kingdom of God, but this is not the primary thought.
The mention of an ordinary feast might have made the rebuke too pointed.
But this result is not the main reason for not taking the highest place.
Archibald T. Robertson: Periphrastic perfect passive subjunctive of καλεω after μη ποτε.
John Gill: Sit not down in the highest room: in the chief place at table, as soon as come in."
Lest a more honourable man...be bidden of him: the master of the feast.
And who may not yet be come, and for whom the chief place may be designed, and will better suit him.

bhtAttempts.bht: In this verse, Jesus teaches about humility and warns against false humility, urging his listeners to avoid seeking the highest place at a feast. The true exaltation from the Host is not achieved through self-promotion but through genuine humility. The mention of a wedding feast points to the Kingdom of God and the deeper meaning behind this parable. Jesus deliberately avoids personal references, using the analogy of a different kind of entertainment. Instead of taking the chief place at the table, Jesus advises his followers not to sit down in the highest room, in case a more honorable person is bidden and deserves that place.

Jesus teaches about avoiding false humility and seeking the highest place at a feast in this passage. He emphasizes that true exaltation comes from the Host and not through self-promotion. The mention of a wedding feast relates to the Kingdom of God. Jesus tactfully avoids personal references and alludes to a different kind of entertainment. Instead of taking the chief place at the table, he advises against sitting in the highest room, leaving space for a more honorable person who may be better suited for that position.

The mention of a wedding feast points to the deeper meaning of the Kingdom of God. Jesus avoids personal references, alluding to a different kind of entertainment. Instead of taking the chief place at the table, he advises against sitting in the highest room, as a more honorable person might be bidden and better suited for that position.

The mention of a wedding feast points to the deeper meaning of the Kingdom of God. Jesus avoids personal references, alluding to a different kind of entertainment. Instead of taking the chief place, he advises against sitting in the highest room, as a more honorable person might be bidden and better suited for that position.

Jesus instructs against false humility and the desire for the highest place at a feast. He highlights that true exaltation comes from the Host and is not achieved through self-promotion. The mention of a wedding feast reflects the significance of the Kingdom of God. Jesus avoids personal references, subtly alluding to a different type of gathering. Instead of assuming the chief place, he cautions against sitting in the highest room, as someone more honorable may be invited and better suited for that position.
